'''Anthony J. (Tony) Sisti''' (1901–1983) was an American [[artist]], art instructor and patron of the arts.  In his youth, Sisti was also a [[Bantamweight|Bantam Weight]] [[boxing|boxer]].  As an artist, Sisti was best known for his oil paintings, drawings, and murals.

Sisti studied at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in [[Florence, Italy|Florence]], [[Italy]].  He then taught at the [[Art Institute of Buffalo]] before opening his own gallery in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York (state)|New York]].  Over the years, he painted portraits of many important political and business leaders.  In 1981, the City of Buffalo named a park in his honor.

== Life ==

Sisti was born in [[Greenwich Village]] in 1901.  He moved to Buffalo when he was ten.  As a young man, Sisti began boxing at a local gym.  A year later, he won the New York State’s 1918 [[Golden Gloves]] bantamweight championship.  At that point, he became a professional boxer.  Over the next twelve years, he boxed whenever he needed money.  When he finally retired in 1930, he had fought 100 bouts, winning all but 15.  However, his real passion was art.<ref name="TM">[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,760842,00.html?iid=digg_share "Practical Anatomy"], ''Time'', Time, Inc., New York, New York, 6 March 1939.</ref><ref name="BSC">[http://buffaloah.com/a/elmwd/1300/bp/1a/source/19.html "Buffalo as an Architectural Museum"], Burchfield-Penney Art Center, Buffalo State College, Buffalo, New York, 14 May 2009.</ref>

From 1926 to 1931, Sisti studied visual arts at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Florence, eventually earning a doctor's degree in painting.  During this period, he also traveled throughout Europe.  He also accompanied [[Ernest Hemingway]] on a trip to the [[Congo Basin|Congo]]. When he ran out of money, Sisti arranged a boxing match in [[Rome]], winning enough money to finance his return to Buffalo.  Later, he used the winnings from another fight to underwrite the cost a personal art show in [[New York City]].<ref name="TM"/><ref name="BSC"/><ref name="NYT">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9402E0D81738F934A25751C1A965948260 "Anthony Sisti Is Dead at 82; Boxer Who Became an Artist"], Obituaries, Associated Press, ''New York Times'', New York, New York, 17 December 1983.</ref>

[[File:Circus, oil painting by Tony Sisti, 1934.jpg|left|thumb|Oil painting entitled ''Circus'' by Tony Sisti, 1934]]Sisti joined the Art Institute of Buffalo as a member of the faculty in 1932.  He taught painting and anatomy at the institute until 1938.<ref name="AA">[http://www.askart.com/AskART/artists/biography.aspx?searchtype=BIO&artist=105673 "Tony Sisti"], AskART on-line database, ''www.askart.com'', 2008.</ref>  During the mid-1930s, he also won several [[Works Projects Administration]] art commissions including a large oil painting called ''Circus'' and a mural at Buffalo’s City Hospital.  Unfortunately, the mural no longer exists.<ref name="BSC"/>

In 1938, he opened his own art studio on Franklin Street in the Allentown area of Buffalo.  He continued to teach art as well, flying to Manhattan every week to teach drawing at the [[New York School of Applied Design for Women]].<ref name="TM"/>  Over the years, Sisti became an active member of the Allentown community.  In 1958, he helped the Allentown neighborhood organize an outdoor art festival, serving as the event’s first chairman.  Fifty years later, the ''Allentown Art Festival'' is still a popular annual event in Buffalo.<ref>Hausmann, Anna, [http://www.buffalospree.com/archives/2003_0506/050603festival.html "The Art of the Festival How the Allentown Art Festival makes it work"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015150223/http://www.buffalospree.com/archives/2003_0506/050603festival.html |date=2008-10-15 }}, ''Buffalo Spree'', Buffalo, New York, May/June 2003.</ref>

In 1979, Sisti made a major gift to the [[Burchfield-Penney Art Center]], including 26 paintings and drawings by [[Charles E. Burchfield]] as well as 32 of his own works.<ref>[http://www.wrightnowinbuffalo.com/ “Museum Exhibit Opening”], Buffalo Niagara, Buffalo Niagara Convention & Visitors Bureau, www.wrightnowinbuffalo.com, Buffalo, New York, 14 May 2009.</ref><ref name="BPC">[http://www.yournewburchfieldpenney.com/?select=exhibitions&data=exhibitions "Tony Sisti: Forgotten Regionalist"], Burchfield-Penney Art Center, Buffalo State College, Buffalo, New York, 14 May 2009.</ref>  In 1981, the City of Buffalo named a park in the Allentown area in his honor.  Tony Sisti Park is located near the intersection of Franklin Street and North Street.<ref name="AV">[http://artvoice.com/issues/v8n15/tony_sisti "Tony Sisti: Gone, but Hardly Forgotten"], ''ARTVOICE'', Buffalo, New York, 8 April 2009.</ref>

Sisti died in Buffalo on 15 December 1983.<ref name="NYT"/>  More than twenty-five years later, he is still remembered in Buffalo as a painter, art collector, and patron of the arts.  In 2009, when the Burchfield-Penney Art Center opened its new museum on the campus of [[Buffalo State College]], one of the main floor galleries was named after Sisti.<ref name="BSC"/><ref name="AV"/>

== Art work ==
[[File:Portrait of Buffalo Mayor Steven Pankow by Tony Sisti, 1957.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Buffalo Mayor Steven Pankow, 1957]]
Tony Sisti was a [[Painting|painter]], [[muralist]], and [[drawing]] specialist.  He was a classically trained artist, who studied at the Albright Art School in Buffalo and at Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Florence.  He later became an art instructor at the Art Institute of Buffalo and then the New York School of Applied Design for Women in New York City.  He was active as a professional painter from the mid-1920s until his death in 1983.<ref name="BSC"/><ref name="NYT"/><ref name="AA"/><ref name="BPC"/><ref name="AV"/>

Sisti was known for his bold use of color and fluid action figures.  He was an accomplished landscape painter, but he was especially noted for his paintings of boxing and other action scenes.  His portrait of heavy weight contender Phil Muscato, titled ''The Boxer'', won the Gold Medal at the 1953 Buffalo Society of Artists exhibition.<ref name="BSC"/>

He was also well known as a formal portrait painter.  President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], New York Governor [[Alfred E. Smith]], and [[Fiat|Fiat Motor Company]] president [[Giovanni Agnelli]] were among the notable individuals who had portraits painted by Sisti.<ref name="NYT"/><ref name="BPC"/>  He also painter official portraits of at least one Buffalo mayor and a number of other Buffalo city officials.<ref>[http://www.ci.buffalo.ny.us/files/1_2_1/Public%20Art%20Website/Web%20Pages/Steven%20Pankow.html "Steven Pankow"], City of Buffalo Leadership, Buffalo Arts Commission, City of Buffalo, New York, 16 May 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.ci.buffalo.ny.us/files/1_2_1/Public%20Art%20Website/Web%20Pages/Elmer%20Lux.html "Elmer J. Lux"], City of Buffalo Leadership, Buffalo Arts Commission, City of Buffalo, New York, 16 May 2009.</ref>

Sisti’s works have been exhibited in major museums including the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York, the [[Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts]], and the Burchfield-Penney Art Center in Buffalo.  The Burchfield-Penney Art Center also displays a number of Sisti’s paintings in its permanent collection.<ref name="AA"/><ref name="BPC"/><ref name="AV"/>
